stem: Before servicing energized equipment (e.g., boiler controls), the safest standard approach is to:
choices: Work live to avoid resetting controls
Lockout/tagout, verify zero energy, then proceed
Turn off one breaker and start immediately
Wear gloves and proceed without isolating power
explanation: Lockout/tagout with verification (test before touch) is the standard to control hazardous energy.

references.note: Use your site LOTO procedure and WorkSafeBC guidance.

stem: When working in a mechanical room with gas appliances, the FIRST action if you smell gas is to:
choices: Turn on exhaust fans and continue working
Ignite the appliance to burn off the gas
Evacuate/ventilate safely, avoid ignition sources, and follow emergency procedure
Open a flame to locate the leak
explanation: Treat gas odour as an emergency: avoid ignition sources, ventilate if safe, evacuate, and follow site emergency procedures.

references.note: Follow your employer and local gas utility emergency steps.

stem: Eye protection is MOST critical when:
choices: Sweeping floors
Soldering/cutting/grinding or using compressed air to blow out lines
Filling out paperwork
Listening for pipe noise
explanation: Cutting/grinding, soldering, and compressed air can propel debris and cause burnsâ€”eye protection is essential.

stem: A confined space is MOST accurately described as a space that:
choices: Is any small room
Is designed for continuous occupancy
Has limited entry/exit and may have hazardous atmosphere or other hazards
Has a door that can lock
explanation: Confined spaces have restricted entry/exit and are not intended for continuous occupancy; atmospheric hazards may exist.

references.note: Confirm permit, testing, ventilation and rescue requirements in WorkSafeBC regs.

stem: The BEST way to protect yourself from scalding when testing domestic hot water is to:
choices: Use your hand to test temperature quickly
Open the hot tap fully immediately
Open slowly, use a thermometer, and be aware of mixing valve settings
Only test after turning up the boiler setpoint
explanation: Open slowly and measure temperature; scald protection is managed by safe procedures and properly set mixing valves.

references.note: Verify local requirements for max delivery temperature where applicable.

stem: When lifting heavy equipment (e.g., pumps, water heaters), the safest approach is to:
choices: Twist while lifting to save time
Lift with a rounded back to keep it close
Use mechanical assistance/team lift and keep load close with neutral spine
Lift quickly to reduce strain time
explanation: Use proper manual handling: neutral spine, load close, avoid twisting, and use mechanical aids or team lifts.

stem: When using a ladder, the recommended setup angle is commonly described as:
explanation: The 4:1 rule is a standard ladder-angle guideline for stability and safe climbing.

references.note: Confirm against the current WorkSafeBC ladder guidance used by your employer.

stem: Before cutting into a pipe that may be under pressure, you should FIRST:
choices: Cut quickly and control the spray
Verify isolation, depressurize, and confirm no stored pressure remains
Heat the pipe to reduce pressure
Open nearby fixtures only
explanation: Confirm isolation and depressurization to prevent injury, water damage, and uncontrolled release.

stem: When working with chemical descalers/cleaners, the MOST important first step is to:
choices: Mix different products to increase strength
Read the SDS/label and use required PPE and ventilation
Use hot water to activate fumes
Store open containers for quick access
explanation: SDS/label provides hazards, PPE, ventilation, first aid, and handling instructions.

references.note: Follow WHMIS training and site chemical handling policy.

stem: When soldering near combustible materials, the BEST precaution is to:
choices: Use a larger torch flame to finish faster
Use a heat shield/fire blanket and have a fire watch/extinguisher available
Spray water continuously on the flame
Ignore combustibles if the joint is small
explanation: Use shielding and appropriate fire precautions to prevent ignition; follow hot-work controls as required.

references.note: Many workplaces require hot-work permits and a fire watch.

stem: Hearing protection is MOST appropriate when:
choices: Working in quiet offices
Using loud power tools (e.g., grinders) or in high-noise mechanical rooms
Soldering small copper joints
Measuring pipe lengths
explanation: High-noise tools/areas can exceed safe exposure limits; hearing protection prevents long-term hearing loss.

stem: The BEST way to prevent slips/trips in a work area is to:
choices: Ignore small spills
Keep housekeeping tight: clean spills, manage cords/hoses, and keep walkways clear
Wear any shoes
Move faster through the area
explanation: Housekeeping and hazard control reduces common injuries from slips/trips/falls.

stem: If you suspect carbon monoxide (CO) exposure, the BEST immediate action is to:
choices: Continue working with doors closed
Move to fresh air immediately and follow emergency procedures
Turn up the boiler to improve draft
Smell-check the flue joints closely
explanation: CO is dangerous and can be fatal. Move to fresh air and follow emergency response procedures.

references.note: Confirm site emergency actions; call emergency services if required.

stem: Before starting a job, the BEST way to reduce rework and hazards is to:
choices: Start immediately to save time
Do a quick hazard assessment, confirm scope, isolate services, and plan the sequence
Only check tools after the job is done
Wait for someone else to plan
explanation: Planning + hazard assessment + isolations reduce incidents and rework.

stem: A Job Hazard Analysis (JHA) is primarily used to:
choices: Calculate pipe sizing
Identify hazards, assess risks, and apply controls before work starts
Choose pipe material based on cost
Set boiler temperature curves
explanation: JHA/JSA documents hazards and controls (PPE, isolation, barriers, procedures) before performing the work.

references.note: Use your workplace hazard assessment form/process.

stem: After completing a repair on a potable water line, the BEST final step before leaving is to:
choices: Leave immediately if it looks dry
Confirm operation, check for leaks under pressure, and restore area/notify client
Turn water off permanently
Only photograph the repair
explanation: Verify under operating conditions and ensure the system is safe, leak-free, and the area is restored/communicated.
